close_symbols: type of the daemon member (e.g. struct MHD_Daemon or typedef used for c->daemon)
explanation:
- struct MHD_Connection (full definition): needed to see the exact types of members accessed (suspended, connection_timeout_ms, last_activity, daemon) and to determine whether any member is written to or has qualifiers (volatile, etc.). This is the primary symbol to decide if the incoming pointer parameter can be const-qualified (i.e. the function only reads members).
- type of the daemon member (struct MHD_Daemon or the typedef used): the code passes c->daemon into MHD_DLOG; we need the daemon member type to check type/qualification compatibility when the enclosing MHD_Connection pointer is made const (member-level vs pointed-to const qualifiers).
- MHD_DLOG (macro or function prototype/declaration): MHD_DLOG is invoked with c->daemon; its declared parameter types determine whether passing the (potentially const-qualified) member from a const struct would be type-compatible or would require dropping constness (which would prevent making the MHD_Connection pointer const). Also macros can have hidden side-effects that could write through the daemon pointer.
- MHD_monotonic_msec_counter (prototype): although it takes no MHD_Connection argument, its declaration confirms it does not take or mutate the connection; included so the analyzer can rule out any indirect mutation of c via this call when considering const qualification of the parameter.
